answer_html: The values we get are \(\lambda = 1,\frac{1}{6},\frac{-1}{6}\)These are the eigenvalues of Matrix A and it shows that 1 is an eigenvalue
answer_latex:
The values we get are $\lambda = 1,\frac{1}{6},\frac{-1}{6}$These are the eigenvalues of Matrix A and it shows that 1 is an
eigenvalue
question: 4 (a)
sols_html:
The eigenvalues are given by the formula

\(det(A-\lambda * I) = \left| \begin{array}{ccc} a_{1 1} - \lambda & a_{1 2} & a_{1 3} \\ a_{2 1} & a_{2 2} - \lambda & a_{2 3} \\ a_{3 1} & a_{3 2} & a_{3 3} - \lambda \end{array} \right| = 0\)

Doing this gives the following polynomial

\(-\lambda^{3}+\lambda^2+\frac{1}{36}\lambda-\frac{1}{36} = 0\)

The values we get are \(\lambda = 1,\frac{1}{6},\frac{-1}{6}\)

These are the eigenvalues of Matrix A and it shows that 1 is an eigenvalue
sols_latex:
The eigenvalues are given by the formula

$det(A-\lambda * I) = \left| \begin{array}{ccc}
a_{1 1} - \lambda & a_{1 2} & a_{1 3} \\
a_{2 1} & a_{2 2} - \lambda & a_{2 3} \\
a_{3 1} & a_{3 2} & a_{3 3} - \lambda \end{array} \right| = 0$

Doing this gives the following polynomial

$-\lambda^{3}+\lambda^2+\frac{1}{36}\lambda-\frac{1}{36} = 0$

The values we get are $\lambda = 1,\frac{1}{6},\frac{-1}{6}$

These are the eigenvalues of Matrix A and it shows that 1 is an
eigenvalue

The eigenvalues are given by the formula

<math>det(A-\lambda * I) = \left| \begin{array}{ccc}
a_{1 1} - \lambda & a_{1 2} & a_{1 3} \\
a_{2 1} & a_{2 2} - \lambda & a_{2 3} \\
a_{3 1} & a_{3 2} & a_{3 3} - \lambda \end{array} \right| = 0</math>

Doing this gives the following polynomial

<math>-\lambda^{3}+\lambda^2+\frac{1}{36}\lambda-\frac{1}{36} = 0</math>

The values we get are <math>\lambda = 1,\frac{1}{6},\frac{-1}{6}</math>

These are the eigenvalues of Matrix A and it shows that 1 is an eigenvalue
statement_html:
The following discrete dynamical system describes the yearly migration of wild horse populations among three areas R, G, and B. Let r(t), g(t), and b(t) be the sizes of the horse population in areas R, G, and B respectively at the tth year.

\[\begin{aligned} x(t+1) &= \begin{bmatrix} r(t+1) \\ g(t+1) \\ b(t+1) \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/3 \\ r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/2 \\ g(t)/3 + b(t)/6 \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/3 \\ 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/2 \\ 0 & 1/3 & 1/6 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} r(t) \\ g(t) \\ b(t) \end{bmatrix} \\ &= Ax(t)\end{aligned}\]

Where the Markov matrix A describes how the horses move among these areas from one year to the next. The 1st column indicates that each year 1/2 of the horses in area R remain in area R and 1/2 will migrate to area G. The 2nd column shows that horses in area G will be evenly distributed in the three areas one year later. The 3rd column implies that, of the horses in area B, 1/3 will migrate to area R, 1/2 will migrate to area G, and only 1/6 will remain in area B.

We assume that no horses are lost and no new horses are added and that initially (i.e. at t = 0), there are a total of 350 horses all located in area B. Thus \(\vec x(0) = [0\ 0\ 350]^T\).

(a) Show that \(\lambda\)3 = 1 is an eigenvalue of A. Then, find the other two eigenvalues \(\lambda\)1 and \(\lambda\)2.
statement_latex:
The following discrete dynamical system describes the yearly migration
of wild horse populations among three areas R, G, and B. Let
\emph{r(t)}, \emph{g(t)}, and \emph{b(t)} be the sizes of the horse
population in areas R, G, and B respectively at the
\emph{t\textsuperscript{th}} year.

\begin{align*}
x(t+1) &= \begin{bmatrix} r(t+1) \\ g(t+1) \\ b(t+1) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/3 \\
r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/2 \\
g(t)/3 + b(t)/6
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/3 \\ 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/2 \\ 0 & 1/3 & 1/6 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} r(t) \\ g(t) \\ b(t) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= Ax(t)
\end{align*}

Where the Markov matrix \emph{A} describes how the horses move among
these areas from one year to the next. The 1st column indicates that
each year 1/2 of the horses in area R remain in area R and 1/2 will
migrate to area G. The 2nd column shows that horses in area G will be
evenly distributed in the three areas one year later. The 3rd column
implies that, of the horses in area B, 1/3 will migrate to area R, 1/2
will migrate to area G, and only 1/6 will remain in area B.

We assume that no horses are lost and no new horses are added and that
initially (i.e. at \emph{t = 0}), there are a total of 350 horses all
located in area B. Thus $\vec x(0) = [0\ 0\ 350]^T$.

\textbf{(a)} Show that \emph{$\lambda$\textsubscript{3} = 1} is an eigenvalue of
\emph{A}. Then, find the other two eigenvalues \emph{$\lambda$\textsubscript{1}}
and \emph{$\lambda$\textsubscript{2}}.
statement_raw:
The following discrete dynamical system describes the yearly migration of wild horse populations among three areas R, G, and B. Let ''r(t)'', ''g(t)'', and ''b(t)'' be the sizes of the horse population in areas R, G, and B respectively at the ''t<sup>th</sup>'' year.

:<math>\begin{align}
x(t+1) &= \begin{bmatrix} r(t+1) \\ g(t+1) \\ b(t+1) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/3 \\
r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/2 \\
g(t)/3 + b(t)/6
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/3 \\ 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/2 \\ 0 & 1/3 & 1/6 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} r(t) \\ g(t) \\ b(t) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= Ax(t)
\end{align}</math>

Where the Markov matrix ''A'' describes how the horses move among these areas from one year to the next. The 1st column indicates that each year 1/2 of the horses in area R remain in area R and 1/2 will migrate to area G. The 2nd column shows that horses in area G will be evenly distributed in the three areas one year later. The 3rd column implies that, of the horses in area B, 1/3 will migrate to area R, 1/2 will migrate to area G, and only 1/6 will remain in area B.

We assume that no horses are lost and no new horses are added and that initially (i.e. at ''t = 0''), there are a total of 350 horses all located in area B. Thus <math>\vec x(0) = [0\ 0\ 350]^T</math>.

'''(a)''' Show that ''&lambda;<sub>3</sub> = 1'' is an eigenvalue of ''A''. Then, find the other two eigenvalues ''&lambda;<sub>1</sub>'' and ''&lambda;<sub>2</sub>''.
